bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Keston College, originally founded in 1969 as the Center for the Study of Religion and Communism with the named changed to Keston College in 1974, collected and publicized details about religious persecution behind the Iron Curtain, becoming “the voice of the voiceless.” After the collapse of communism in the 1990s, Keston College moved to Oxford and downsized due to decreased funding. The name eventually changed to Keston Institute. In 2007, the Institute transferred the Keston Archive and Library to the newly created Keston Center for Religion, Politics, and Society at Baylor University.

Keston collected, verified, translated, and disseminated information received from believers in the Soviet Union, Poland, Romania, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and other communist countries. The Keston Archive and Library housed numerous letters, petitions, reports and underground publications (Samizdat) from believers of various denominations along with officially published books and periodicals.
Keston collected files related to Hinduism in the Soviet Union from 1962 through 1982. The main focus is persecution of Soviet Hindus.

Historically, the primary spread of Hinduism within the Russia came through the country’s Indian population. The earliest evidence of Hinduism within Russian lands appears to be a Vishnu idol found in Staraya Maina; although, the first prominent group of Hindus likely lived around Astrakhan, a region claimed by the country in the mid-1500s. During the reign of Peter the Great, Hinduism became a protected religion. Nonetheless, the group remains a minority religion within Russia. The Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life approximates that in the early 2000s, fewer than 0.1% of Russians adhered to Hinduism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Soviet Union Hinduism Files contain bibliographies, cross references, newspaper clippings, and a book excerpt. These documents span from 1962 to 1982. The content addresses the persecution of Hindus in the Soviet Union, mentions the Hare Krishna group, and explains yogis. Specific forms of persecution reviewed include arrests and house searches. The subject files also contain information about how the Soviet Union government viewed Gandhi and his movement within India.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Keston Center received the Soviet Union Hindu documents in one folder. Some documents were labeled and were filed accordingly. All files are organized by date.
